title: Two Red Sox outfielders earn Gold Glove Awards
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Wilyer Abreu and Ceddanne Rafaela of the Red Sox win 2025 Gold Glove Awards for right and center field.
Abreu is a two-time Gold Glove winner, leading A.L. right fielders with eight Outs Above Average.
Rafaela wins his first Gold Glove, leading A.L. centerfielders with 21 Outs Above Average and 19 runs prevented.

title: Middle school principal in Maine draws criticism after dressing as ICE agent for Halloween
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Mt. Blue Middle School principal James Black criticized for dressing as ICE agent for Halloween off school grounds.
Superintendent Christian Elkington noted the incident raised concerns but occurred off RSU #9 property.
Advocacy group Project Relief Maine condemned the costume, citing fear it might instill in immigrant students.

title: What Christian Gonzalez said about his head injury
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Patriots' Christian Gonzalez left the game with a head injury but later confirmed he was fine after passing concussion protocol.
The injury happened as Gonzalez competed with Falcons' Drake London on a 40-yard catch, London's biggest play of the game.
The Patriots secured a one-point victory after a missed extra point from the Falcons, marking their closest win this season.

title: South End residents say they picked up 180 needles in less than a week at neighborhood park
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: South End volunteers collected 180 needles in six days from Southwest Corridor Park, highlighting drug issues in the area.
City of Boston distributes over 81,000 needles monthly for harm reduction, a 22% decrease from 2024.
Councilor Ed Flynn calls for reduced needle distribution and increased support for recovery services and public safety.

title: What Kevin Durant said about Jayson Tatum’s Achilles recovery, chances of returning this year
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Kevin Durant praised Jayson Tatum's quick recovery from Achilles surgery, noting advancements in medical treatment since his own injury.
Tatum could potentially return in the 2025-26 season, a significant shift from initial expectations of a longer recovery.
Durant, Tatum's former Olympic teammate, believes Tatum's passion for the game will drive him to return as soon as possible.

title: Amid tragedy, childhood friends DeMario Douglas and Terrell Jennings persevere in Patriots’ win
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: DeMario Douglas and Terrell Jennings overcame personal tragedy to excel in the Patriots' 24-23 win over the Falcons.
Douglas recorded his first 100-yard NFL game and a touchdown following the death of a close family member.
Jennings, promoted from the practice squad, scored his first NFL touchdown amid injuries in the Patriots' lineup.

title: Mike Vrabel shares message to Patriots, Drake Maye after nail-biting win over Falcons
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots narrowly defeated the Atlanta Falcons 24-23 at Gillette Stadium despite multiple missed opportunities and turnovers.
Coach Mike Vrabel emphasized maintaining joy and resilience in football after the Patriots' uneven performance led to a win.
Quarterback Drake Maye acknowledged his turnovers but highlighted the importance of appreciating victories and learning from games.

title: Former Newton Mayor Setti Warren dies ‘unexpectedly’ at 55
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Setti Warren, former Newton Mayor, died unexpectedly at 55 on Sunday at his home in Newton.
Warren was the first African American mayor of a Massachusetts city, serving Newton from 2009 to 2018.
He held roles in the Clinton administration, Navy Reserve, and was Harvard's Institute of Politics Director.

title: Patriots stock watch: Here’s who stood out and struggled against Falcons
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: DeMario Douglas had a standout performance, earning his first career 100-yard game with several big plays, including a 58-yard catch.
Quarterback Drake Maye faced pressure, was sacked six times, and committed two turnovers, though he managed several significant throws.
Atlanta capitalized on height mismatches, targeting Marcus Jones in the red zone for two touchdowns during the Patriots' close victory.

title: Boston residents say they feel safer downtown compared to last year in new survey
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Survey shows 33.7% of residents feel less safe downtown, down from 70.6% in November 2024.
Public safety summit addressed drug use, petty crime, and infrastructure concerns in downtown Boston.
Retail vacancies at lowest since pandemic, attributed to increased sense of safety by Downtown Boston Alliance.
